name: 1613_E. Crazy Robot
description:
There is a grid, consisting of n rows and m columns. Each cell of the grid is either free or blocked. One of the free cells contains a lab. All the cells beyond the borders of the grid are also blocked.

A crazy robot has escaped from this lab. It is currently in some free cell of the grid. You can send one of the following commands to the robot: "move right", "move down", "move left" or "move up". Each command means moving to a neighbouring cell in the corresponding direction.

However, as the robot is crazy, it will do anything except following the command. Upon receiving a command, it will choose a direction such that it differs from the one in command and the cell in that direction is not blocked. If there is such a direction, then it will move to a neighbouring cell in that direction. Otherwise, it will do nothing.

We want to get the robot to the lab to get it fixed. For each free cell, determine if the robot can be forced to reach the lab starting in this cell. That is, after each step of the robot a command can be sent to a robot such that no matter what different directions the robot chooses, it will end up in a lab.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 10^6; n ⋅ m ≤ 10^6) — the number of rows and the number of columns in the grid.

The i-th of the next n lines provides a description of the i-th row of the grid. It consists of m elements of one of three types: 

  * '.' — the cell is free; 
  * '#' — the cell is blocked; 
  * 'L' — the cell contains a lab. 



The grid contains exactly one lab. The sum of n ⋅ m over all testcases doesn't exceed 10^6.

Output

For each testcase find the free cells that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Given the grid, replace the free cells (marked with a dot) with a plus sign ('+') for the cells that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Print the resulting grid.

Example

Input


4
3 3
...
.L.
...
4 5
#....
..##L
...#.
.....
1 1
L
1 9
....L..#.


Output


...
.L.
...
#++++
..##L
...#+
...++
L
++++L++#.

Note

In the first testcase there is no free cell that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Consider a corner cell. Given any direction, it will move to a neighbouring border grid that's not a corner. Now consider a non-corner free cell. No matter what direction you send to the robot, it can choose a different direction such that it ends up in a corner.

In the last testcase, you can keep sending the command that is opposite to the direction to the lab and the robot will have no choice other than move towards the lab.
prompt:
There exists a grid, made up of n rows and m columns. Each cell in the grid is either unoccupied or blocked. One of the unoccupied cells contains a laboratory. All cells outside the grid's limits are also blocked.

A crazy robot has escaped from this lab. It is currently in some free cell of the grid. You can send one of the following commands to the robot: "move right", "move down", "move left" or "move up". Each command means moving to a neighbouring cell in the corresponding direction.

However, because the robot is crazy, it will do anything except obey the command. Upon being given a command, it will select a direction that is not the one specified in the command and where the cell in that direction is not blocked. If there is such a direction, then it will proceed to a neighbouring cell in that direction. Otherwise, it will remain stationary.

We want to get the robot to the lab to get it fixed. For each free cell, determine if the robot can be forced to reach the lab starting in this cell. That is, after each step of the robot a command can be sent to a robot such that no matter what different directions the robot chooses, it will end up in a lab.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 10^6; n ⋅ m ≤ 10^6) — the number of rows and the number of columns in the grid.

The i-th of the next n lines provides a description of the i-th row of the grid. It consists of m elements of one of three types: 

  * '.' — the cell is free; 
  * '#' — the cell is blocked; 
  * 'L' — the cell contains a lab. 



The grid contains exactly one lab. The sum of n ⋅ m over all testcases doesn't exceed 10^6.

Output

For each testcase find the free cells that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Given the grid, replace the free cells (marked with a dot) with a plus sign ('+') for the cells that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Print the resulting grid.

Example

4

Note

In the first testcase there is no free cell that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Consider a corner cell. Given any direction, it will move to a neighbouring border grid that's not a corner. Now consider a non-corner free cell. No matter what direction you send to the robot, it can choose a different direction such that it ends up in a corner.

In the last testcase, you can keep sending the command that is opposite to the direction to the lab and the robot will have no choice other than move towards the lab.
repair_prompt:
There exists a grid, made up of n rows and m columns. Each cell in the grid is either unoccupied or blocked. One of the unoccupied cells contains a laboratory. All cells outside the grid's limits are also blocked.

A crazy robot has escaped from this lab. It is currently in some free cell of the grid. You can send one of the following commands to the robot: "move right", "move down", "move left" or "move up". Each command means moving to a neighbouring cell in the corresponding direction.

However, because the robot is crazy, it will do anything except obey the command. Upon being given a command, it will select a direction that is not the one specified in the command and where the cell in that direction is not blocked. If there is such a direction, then it will proceed to a neighbouring cell in that direction. Otherwise, it will remain stationary.

We want to get the robot to the lab to get it fixed. For each free cell, determine if the robot can be forced to reach the lab starting in this cell. That is, after each step of the robot a command can be sent to a robot such that no matter what different directions the robot chooses, it will end up in a lab.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 10^6; n ⋅ m ≤ 10^6) — the number of rows and the number of columns in the grid.

The i-th of the next n lines provides a description of the i-th row of the grid. It consists of m elements of one of three types: 

  * '.' — the cell is free; 
  * '#' — the cell is blocked; 
  * 'L' — the cell contains a lab. 



The grid contains exactly one lab. The sum of n ⋅ m over all testcases doesn't exceed 10^6.

Output

For each testcase find the free cells that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Given the grid, replace the free cells (marked with a dot) with a plus sign ('+') for the cells that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Print the resulting grid.

-------
Important Note: You must follow the input output format.  The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.
Example

Input


4
3 3
...
.L.
...
4 5
#....
..##L
...#.
.....
1 1
L
1 9
....L..#.


Output


...
.L.
...
#++++
..##L
...#+
...++
L
++++L++#.

Note

In the first testcase there is no free cell that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Consider a corner cell. Given any direction, it will move to a neighbouring border grid that's not a corner. Now consider a non-corner free cell. No matter what direction you send to the robot, it can choose a different direction such that it ends up in a corner.

In the last testcase, you can keep sending the command that is opposite to the direction to the lab and the robot will have no choice other than move towards the lab.

from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Finds the free cells from which the robot can be forced to reach the lab.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing grid dimensions and grid data.

    Returns:
        List[List[str]]: Modified grids for each test case with reachable cells marked.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, grid in test_cases:
        # Convert grid to a list of lists for mutability
        grid = [list(row) for row in grid]
        
        # Find the lab position
        lab_position = None
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_position = (i, j)
                    break
            if lab_position:
                break

        # Directions for BFS: right, down, left, up
        directions = [(0, 1), (1, 0), (0, -1), (-1, 0)]

        # BFS to find all reachable cells
        queue = deque([lab_position])
        visited = set([lab_position])

        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()

            # Check all four possible directions
            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy

                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and (nx, ny) not in visited:
                    if grid[nx][ny] == '.':
                        # Check if the cell can be forced to reach the lab
                        free_directions = 0
                        for ddx, ddy in directions:
                            nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                            if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                                free_directions += 1
                        if free_directions <= 1:
                            grid[nx][ny] = '+'
                            queue.append((nx, ny))
                            visited.add((nx, ny))

        # Convert grid back to list of strings
        results.append([''.join(row) for row in grid])

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input().strip())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, input().strip().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, grid))

    # Output interface
    results = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        for row in result:
            print(row)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py
from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    def bfs(n: int, m: int, grid: List[str]) -> List[str]:
        # Find the lab position
        lab_position = None
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_position = (i, j)
                    break
            if lab_position:
                break
        
        # Directions for BFS: right, down, left, up
        directions = [(0, 1), (1, 0), (0, -1), (-1, 0)]
        
        # Initialize the queue for BFS and visited set
        queue = deque([lab_position])
        visited = set([lab_position])
        
        # Convert grid to a list of lists for mutability
        grid = [list(row) for row in grid]
        
        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()
            
            # Check all possible directions
            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy
                
                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and (nx, ny) not in visited:
                    if grid[nx][ny] == '.':
                        # Count free neighbors
                        free_neighbors = 0
                        for ddx, ddy in directions:
                            nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                            if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                                free_neighbors += 1
                        
                        # If the cell has only one free neighbor, mark it as reachable
                        if free_neighbors <= 1:
                            grid[nx][ny] = '+'
                            queue.append((nx, ny))
                    
                    visited.add((nx, ny))
        
        # Convert grid back to list of strings
        return [''.join(row) for row in grid]

    # Process each test case
    result = []
    for n, m, grid in test_cases:
        result.append(bfs(n, m, grid))
    
    return result

# Input interface
t = int(input())
test_cases = []
for _ in range(t):
    n, m = map(int, input().split())
    grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
    test_cases.append((n, m, grid))

# Output interface
result = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)
for grid in result:
    for row in grid:
        print(row)
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Finds the free cells from which the robot can be forced to reach the lab.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing the grid dimensions and the grid itself.

    Returns:
        List[List[str]]: List of grids with free cells replaced by '+' if the robot can be forced to reach the lab from there.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, grid in test_cases:
        # Convert grid to a list of lists for mutability
        grid = [list(row) for row in grid]
        
        # Find the position of the lab
        lab_position = None
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_position = (i, j)
                    break
            if lab_position:
                break

        # Directions for BFS: right, down, left, up
        directions = [(0, 1), (1, 0), (0, -1), (-1, 0)]

        # BFS to find all reachable cells from the lab
        queue = deque([lab_position])
        visited = set([lab_position])

        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()

            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy

                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and (nx, ny) not in visited:
                    if grid[nx][ny] == '.':
                        # Check if the cell can be forced to reach the lab
                        free_directions = 0
                        for ddx, ddy in directions:
                            nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                            if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                                free_directions += 1
                        if free_directions <= 1:
                            grid[nx][ny] = '+'
                            queue.append((nx, ny))
                            visited.add((nx, ny))

        # Convert grid back to list of strings
        results.append([''.join(row) for row in grid])

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input().strip())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, input().strip().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, grid))

    # Output interface
    result = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)
    for grid in result:
        for row in grid:
            print(row)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Find free cells from which the robot can be forced to reach the lab.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing grid dimensions and grid data.

    Returns:
        List[List[str]]: List of processed grids with reachable cells marked.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, grid in test_cases:
        # Convert grid to a list of lists for easier manipulation
        grid = [list(row) for row in grid]
        
        # Find the position of the lab
        lab_position = None
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_position = (i, j)
                    break
            if lab_position:
                break
        
        # Initialize BFS structures
        queue = deque([lab_position])
        visited = set([lab_position])
        
        # Directions for BFS: up, down, left, right
        directions = [(-1, 0), (1, 0), (0, -1), (0, 1)]
        
        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()
            
            # Check all four possible directions
            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy
                
                # Check if the new position is within bounds and is a free cell
                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and grid[nx][ny] == '.':
                    # Count free neighbors
                    free_neighbors = 0
                    for ddx, ddy in directions:
                        nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                        if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                            free_neighbors += 1
                    
                    # If the cell has at most one free neighbor, mark it as reachable
                    if free_neighbors <= 1:
                        grid[nx][ny] = '+'
                        queue.append((nx, ny))
                        visited.add((nx, ny))
        
        # Convert grid back to list of strings for output
        results.append([''.join(row) for row in grid])
    
    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, grid))
    
    # Call the function
    results = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)
    
    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        for row in result:
            print(row)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[List[str]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Finds the free cells from which the robot can be forced to reach the lab.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[List[str]]): List of grids for each test case.

    Returns:
        List[List[str]]: Modified grids with reachable cells marked.
    """
    results = []

    for grid in test_cases:
        n = len(grid)
        m = len(grid[0])
        lab_position = None
        grid = [list(row) for row in grid]

        # Find the lab position
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_position = (i, j)
                    break
            if lab_position:
                break

        # BFS to find all reachable cells from the lab
        if lab_position:
            queue = deque([lab_position])
            visited = set([lab_position])

            while queue:
                x, y = queue.popleft()

                # Check all four possible directions
                for dx, dy in [(-1, 0), (1, 0), (0, -1), (0, 1)]:
                    nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy

                    if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and (nx, ny) not in visited:
                        if grid[nx][ny] == '.':
                            # Check if the cell can be forced to reach the lab
                            free_directions = 0
                            for ddx, ddy in [(-1, 0), (1, 0), (0, -1), (0, 1)]:
                                nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                                if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                                    free_directions += 1

                            if free_directions <= 1:
                                grid[nx][ny] = '+'
                                queue.append((nx, ny))
                                visited.add((nx, ny))
                        elif grid[nx][ny] == 'L':
                            queue.append((nx, ny))
                            visited.add((nx, ny))

        # Convert grid back to list of strings
        results.append([''.join(row) for row in grid])

    return results

# Input interface
if __name__ == "__main__":
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append(grid)

    # Call the function and print the result
    results = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        for line in result:
            print(line)
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Determine which free cells can lead the robot to the lab using BFS.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing grid dimensions and grid.

    Returns:
        List[List[str]]: Modified grids with reachable cells marked.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, grid in test_cases:
        # Convert grid to a list of lists for easier manipulation
        grid = [list(row) for row in grid]
        
        # Find the position of the lab
        lab_position = None
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_position = (i, j)
                    break
            if lab_position:
                break
        
        # Initialize BFS
        queue = deque([lab_position])
        reachable = set([lab_position])
        
        # Directions for BFS: up, down, left, right
        directions = [(-1, 0), (1, 0), (0, -1), (0, 1)]
        
        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()
            
            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy
                
                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and grid[nx][ny] == '.':
                    # Count free neighbors
                    free_neighbors = 0
                    for ddx, ddy in directions:
                        nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                        if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                            free_neighbors += 1
                    
                    # If the cell has at most one free neighbor, it can be forced to reach the lab
                    if free_neighbors <= 1 and (nx, ny) not in reachable:
                        reachable.add((nx, ny))
                        queue.append((nx, ny))
        
        # Mark reachable cells with '+'
        for i, j in reachable:
            if grid[i][j] == '.':
                grid[i][j] = '+'
        
        # Convert grid back to list of strings
        results.append([''.join(row) for row in grid])
    
    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input().strip())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, input().strip().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, grid))
    
    # Call the function
    results = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)
    
    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        for row in result:
            print(row)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Determines which free cells can lead the robot to the lab using BFS.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the grid dimensions and the grid itself.

    Returns:
        A list of grids with reachable cells marked.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, grid in test_cases:
        # Convert grid to a list of lists for easier manipulation
        grid = [list(row) for row in grid]
        
        # Find the lab position
        lab_position = None
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_position = (i, j)
                    break
            if lab_position:
                break
        
        # Directions for BFS: right, down, left, up
        directions = [(0, 1), (1, 0), (0, -1), (-1, 0)]
        
        # BFS setup
        queue = deque([lab_position])
        visited = set([lab_position])
        
        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()
            
            # Check all possible directions
            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy
                
                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and (nx, ny) not in visited:
                    if grid[nx][ny] == '.':
                        # Count free neighbors
                        free_neighbors = 0
                        for ddx, ddy in directions:
                            nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                            if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                                free_neighbors += 1
                        
                        # If the cell has one or fewer free neighbors, mark it as reachable
                        if free_neighbors <= 1:
                            grid[nx][ny] = '+'
                            queue.append((nx, ny))
                    
                    visited.add((nx, ny))
        
        # Convert grid back to list of strings
        results.append([''.join(row) for row in grid])
    
    return results

# Input interface
t = int(input())
test_cases = []
for _ in range(t):
    n, m = map(int, input().split())
    grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
    test_cases.append((n, m, grid))

# Output interface
results = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)
for result in results:
    for row in result:
        print(row)
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Find free cells from which the robot can be forced to reach the lab.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing grid dimensions and grid data.

    Returns:
        List[List[str]]: List of processed grids with reachable cells marked.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, grid in test_cases:
        # Find the position of the lab
        lab_position = None
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_position = (i, j)
                    break
            if lab_position:
                break

        # Initialize BFS structures
        queue = deque([lab_position])
        visited = set([lab_position])
        directions = [(-1, 0), (1, 0), (0, -1), (0, 1)]

        # Perform BFS to find all reachable free cells
        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()
            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy
                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and (nx, ny) not in visited and grid[nx][ny] == '.':
                    # Check if the cell is a forced move cell
                    free_neighbors = 0
                    for ddx, ddy in directions:
                        nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                        if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                            free_neighbors += 1
                    if free_neighbors <= 1:
                        visited.add((nx, ny))
                        queue.append((nx, ny))

        # Prepare the result grid
        result_grid = []
        for i in range(n):
            row = []
            for j in range(m):
                if (i, j) in visited and grid[i][j] == '.':
                    row.append('+')
                else:
                    row.append(grid[i][j])
            result_grid.append(''.join(row))
        results.append(result_grid)

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input().strip())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, input().strip().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, grid))

    # Call the function
    results = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        for line in result:
            print(line)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py
from collections import deque
from typing import List

def process_grid(n: int, m: int, grid: List[str]) -> List[str]:
    """Process the grid to determine which free cells can lead the robot to the lab.

    Args:
        n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
        m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
        grid (List[str]): The grid representation with free cells, blocked cells, and a lab.

    Returns:
        List[str]: The modified grid with reachable free cells marked with '+'.
    """
    # Directions for BFS traversal: right, down, left, up
    directions = [(0, 1), (1, 0), (0, -1), (-1, 0)]
    
    # Find the lab position
    lab_position = None
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(m):
            if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                lab_position = (i, j)
                break
        if lab_position:
            break
    
    # Initialize the queue for BFS and visited set
    queue = deque([lab_position])
    visited = set([lab_position])
    
    # Convert grid to a list of lists for mutability
    grid_list = [list(row) for row in grid]
    
    # Perform BFS from the lab
    while queue:
        x, y = queue.popleft()
        
        for dx, dy in directions:
            nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy
            
            if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and (nx, ny) not in visited:
                if grid_list[nx][ny] == '.':
                    # Count free neighbors
                    free_neighbors = 0
                    for ddx, ddy in directions:
                        nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                        if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid_list[nnx][nny] == '.':
                            free_neighbors += 1
                    
                    # If the cell has at most one free neighbor, mark it as reachable
                    if free_neighbors <= 1:
                        grid_list[nx][ny] = '+'
                        queue.append((nx, ny))
                
                visited.add((nx, ny))
    
    # Convert grid_list back to list of strings
    return [''.join(row) for row in grid_list]

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""
    t = int(input())
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        result = process_grid(n, m, grid)
        for line in result:
            print(line)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Finds the free cells from which the robot can be forced to reach the lab.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the number of rows, number of columns, and the grid.

    Returns:
        A list of grids with free cells marked as '+' if the robot can be forced to reach the lab from them.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, grid in test_cases:
        # Find the position of the lab
        lab_position = None
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_position = (i, j)
                    break
            if lab_position:
                break

        # Initialize BFS
        queue = deque([lab_position])
        visited = set([lab_position])
        directions = [(-1, 0), (1, 0), (0, -1), (0, 1)]
        reachable = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Perform BFS to find all reachable cells
        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()
            reachable[x][y] = True

            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy
                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and (nx, ny) not in visited and grid[nx][ny] == '.':
                    # Check if the cell is a dead-end (only one way to go)
                    free_neighbors = 0
                    for ddx, ddy in directions:
                        nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                        if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                            free_neighbors += 1
                    if free_neighbors <= 1:
                        visited.add((nx, ny))
                        queue.append((nx, ny))

        # Prepare the result grid
        result_grid = []
        for i in range(n):
            row = []
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '.' and reachable[i][j]:
                    row.append('+')
                else:
                    row.append(grid[i][j])
            result_grid.append(''.join(row))
        results.append(result_grid)

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, grid))

    # Output interface
    results = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        for row in result:
            print(row)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

examples:
Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 10^6; n ⋅ m ≤ 10^6) — the number of rows and the number of columns in the grid.

The i-th of the next n lines provides a description of the i-th row of the grid. It consists of m elements of one of three types: 

  * '.' — the cell is free; 
  * '#' — the cell is blocked; 
  * 'L' — the cell contains a lab. 



The grid contains exactly one lab. The sum of n ⋅ m over all testcases doesn't exceed 10^6.

Output

For each testcase find the free cells that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Given the grid, replace the free cells (marked with a dot) with a plus sign ('+') for the cells that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Print the resulting grid.

Example

Input


4
3 3
...
.L.
...
4 5
#....
..##L
...#.
.....
1 1
L
1 9
....L..#.


Output


...
.L.
...
#++++
..##L
...#+
...++
L
++++L++#.

Note

In the first testcase there is no free cell that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Consider a corner cell. Given any direction, it will move to a neighbouring border grid that's not a corner. Now consider a non-corner free cell. No matter what direction you send to the robot, it can choose a different direction such that it ends up in a corner.

In the last testcase, you can keep sending the command that is opposite to the direction to the lab and the robot will have no choice other than move towards the lab.
